title: A look at how we're building more sustainable hardware - The Keyword | Google Product and Technology News
summary: Google is working to reduce its environmental impact by using recycled materials, providing new ways to repair phones, and improving its packaging. In 2022, 30% of all materials used in Google's new products were recycled content, including 48% of all plastic materials. Google has also partnered with iFixit to provide genuine Pixel spare parts, tools and documentation for customers who are skilled in repair. Additionally, Google has reduced Pixel packaging plastic by 97% and reduced the volume of packages by 54% and the weight by over 50% when compared to its first Pixel phone.

green_product: TRUE, Google's Pixel 7 and 7 Pro phones are made with 100 percent recycled aluminum, reducing the carbon footprint of the aluminum portion of the enclosures by over 35% compared to using 100% primary aluminum.
green_process: TRUE, Google's efforts to eliminate plastic from its hardware product packaging by 2025 is an example of a green process.

title: Secondhand fashion has a looming sustainability problem: PFAS - Digital Commerce 360
summary: Several states are banning PFAS chemicals in new apparel, but there is a loophole for continued sale of existing PFAS-made products in second hand markets, even though these chemicals have been linked to cancer and other health impacts. Even as secondhand shopping becomes more popular as a way to save money and make sustainable choices, the issue of PFAS in existing products is not being addressed in the circularity community because there is no easy solution.  Fashion brands like Patagonia, North Face, Canada Goose, and ThredUp have not yet commented on how they are addressing PFAS in their secondhand products.
